section_id: ## 1. Rigorous Formulation of the Mean-Field Revival Operator

hints.label: def-revival-operator-formal
hints.title: Mean-Field Revival Operator (Formal)
hints.content:
104: :label: def-revival-operator-formal
105: 
106: The **revival operator** $\mathcal{R}: \mathcal{P}(\Omega) \times [0,1] \to \mathcal{M}^+(\Omega)$ (where $\mathcal{M}^+$ denotes non-negative measures) is defined by:
107: 
108: $$
109: \mathcal{R}[\rho, m_d](x,v) := \lambda_{\text{revive}} \cdot m_d \cdot \frac{\rho(x,v)}{\|\rho\|_{L^1}}
110: $$
111: 
112: where $\|\rho\|_{L^1} = \int_\Omega \rho(x,v) \, dx dv$ is the total alive mass.
113: 
114: **Properties**:
115: 1. **Mass injection**: $\int_\Omega \mathcal{R}[\rho, m_d] = \lambda_{\text{revive}} m_d$ (transfers mass from dead to alive)
116: 2. **Proportionality**: Revival samples proportionally to current alive density
117: 3. **Normalization**: The factor $1/\|\rho\|_{L^1}$ ensures the distribution shape is preserved

hints.label: def-combined-jump-operator
hints.title: Combined Jump Operator
hints.content:
140: :label: def-combined-jump-operator
141: 
142: Define the **jump operator** $\mathcal{J}: \mathcal{P}(\Omega) \to \mathcal{P}(\Omega)$ that acts over a small time interval $\Delta t$:
143: 
144: $$
145: \mathcal{J}(\rho) := (1 - \int_\Omega \kappa_{\text{kill}} \rho \cdot \Delta t) \cdot \frac{\rho - \kappa_{\text{kill}} \rho \cdot \Delta t}{\text{(normalization)}} + \mathcal{R}[\rho, m_d] \cdot \Delta t
146: $$
147: 
148: This operator:
149: 1. **Removes mass** via killing: $\rho \mapsto \rho - \kappa_{\text{kill}} \rho \cdot \Delta t$
150: 2. **Adds mass** via revival: Injects $\mathcal{R}[\rho, m_d] \cdot \Delta t$
151: 3. **Conserves total mass**: $\int \mathcal{J}(\rho) = \int \rho$ (in the two-population model)

137: For the discrete-time analysis, we consider the **composed** operator that handles both killing and revival in one time step $\Delta t$:
138: 
139: :::{prf:definition} Combined Jump Operator
140: :label: def-combined-jump-operator
141: 
142: Define the **jump operator** $\mathcal{J}: \mathcal{P}(\Omega) \to \mathcal{P}(\Omega)$ that acts over a small time interval $\Delta t$:
143: 
144: $$
145: \mathcal{J}(\rho) := (1 - \int_\Omega \kappa_{\text{kill}} \rho \cdot \Delta t) \cdot \frac{\rho - \kappa_{\text{kill}} \rho \cdot \Delta t}{\text{(normalization)}} + \mathcal{R}[\rho, m_d] \cdot \Delta t
146: $$
147: 
148: This operator:
149: 1. **Removes mass** via killing: $\rho \mapsto \rho - \kappa_{\text{kill}} \rho \cdot \Delta t$
150: 2. **Adds mass** via revival: Injects $\mathcal{R}[\rho, m_d] \cdot \Delta t$
151: 3. **Conserves total mass**: $\int \mathcal{J}(\rho) = \int \rho$ (in the two-population model)
